awd_abstract_narration:
Owing to graphene's unique band structure, two new topological quantum phenomena can emerge: the quantum spin Hall effect (QSHE) and the quantum anomalous Hall effect (QAHE), both offering attractive potential for quantum spintronic applications.  A common prerequisite for these two quantum phenomena is strong spin-orbit coupling, either intrinsic or the Rashba type. Of the two phenomena, QAHE requires additional exchange interaction or ferromagnetism in graphene. Although native graphene has neither interaction, its open and flexible structure allows modifications of the properties by proximity coupling to other materials.  The proposed quantum phenomena based on quantized anomalous Hall effect can be potentially used for dense, robust, low-power, and scalable non-volatile memory which will drastically improve the performance of the current memory devices based on magnetic tunnel junctions. The non-volatile memory devices are ubiquitous in the modern society. High-performance memory devices based on quantum spintronic phenomena will have a significant impact on low power memory. PI proposes to train the undergraduate and graduate students, especially the underrepresented minority students by engaging them with research projects and teaching them newly developed elective courses. The also PI plans to continue outreach activities to a STEM school by coaching the Science Olympiad events  to STEM High school students as well as giving lectures to the summer Physics teachers from southern California high schools during Physics Teacher Summer Academy sponsored by the Physics Department. 

PI's group has successfully demonstrated the anomalous Hall effect in graphene via the proximity coupling with a magnetic insulator.  More recently, PI's group also demonstrated a strong enhancement of spin-orbit coupling via the proximity effect with a transition metal dichalcogenide material (e.g. WS2). In this work, the PI aims to explore the induced effects in all-proximity coupled graphene devices, which acquire new interactions for realizing the predicted quantum effects at relatively high temperatures. Currently few materials are predicted and even fewer materials have been experimentally shown to exhibit QSHE (e.g. HgTe/CdTe quantum wells) and QAHE (e.g. magnetic topological insulators).  These materials are extremely difficult to be synthesized or only show the desired properties at extremely low temperatures. The proposed graphene-based devices are ideal systems in which the required interactions can be induced by proximity effects. Those quantum phenomena have not yet been explored in graphene, but it I expected to show many novel and interesting properties, such as quantized transport, robust Hall voltages, pure spin current, etc. These unmatched properties, if demonstrated at high temperatures, can potentially revolutionize the present-day spin electronics. In this proposed research, the PI plans to demonstrate a prototype quantum spintronic memory device based on QAHE.  The knowledge learned in the graphene-based devices will deepen our fundamental understanding of two-dimensional electron systems with tunable interactions.

por.por_cntn:
The objectives of this report submission period include exploring proximity coupling in van der Waals heterostructure devices, and tailoring and tuning the interactions via 2D material combinations and application of external stimuli. During this report submission period, the PI completed construction of an automated pickup/transfer microscope inside a glovebox; fabricated van der Waals heterostructure devices using the newly constructed microscope; characterized their properties including Raman spectroscopy, atomic force microscopy, photoluminescence, etc.; and investigated the magneto-transport responses over a wide range of temperatures and magnetic fields, and under different electrostatic gate voltages. An important class of new 2D materials that the PI worked on is the layered magnetic materials including Cr2Ge2Te6 (CGT), CrI3, and Fe3GeTe2(FGT). All three layered magnetic materials have their magnetic anisotropy anisotropy perpendicular to the 2D layers. CGT and CrI3 are magnetic insulators with the Curie temperature about 61 K, and FGT is a ferromagnetic metal with the Curie temperature about 225 K.

Outcomes: (1) The PI demonstrated proximity-induced ferromagnetism in paramagnetic Pt by exchange coupling it with atomically flat CGT in CGT/Pt heterostructure devices. This is the first time to demonstrate that the ferromagnetism in paramagnetic conductor can be induced by 2D layered ferromagnetic insulators via the anomalous Hall effect in the paramagnetic Pt. The results were published in Nano Letters in 2019 (M. Lohmann et al., Probing magnetism in insulating Cr2Ge2Te6 by induced anomalous Hall effect in Pt, Nano Lett. 19, 2397 (2019); DOI: 10.1021/acs.nanolett.8b05121).

(2) In FGT/Pt heterostructures, the PI demonstrated the switching of FGT magnetization by the spin-orbit torque (SOT) and quantified spin-orbit torque (SOT) efficiency in FGT/Pt for the first time. An important recent progress in spintronics is the application of SOT in magnetic nano-devices to produce switching or oscillations of magnetization. In FGT/Pt, the SOT efficiency is shown to be about 11%-14%, among the highest in heterostructures of 3D ferromagnetic materials. The high SOT efficiency was attributed to the atomically flat interface which enhances the transmission of spin current generated by the spin Hall effect in Pt. This work appeared in another Nano Letters article in 2019 (M. Alghamdi, Highly efficient spin−orbit torque and switching of layered ferromagnet Fe3GeTe2, Nano Lett. 19, 4400 (2019); DOI: 10.1021/acs.nanolett.9b01043).

(3) In Pt/CrI3 inverted heterostructures, the PI observed induced magnetoresistance effect in Pt due to the spin-flop transition in CrI3. Spin-flop transition in CrI3 is an indication of strong interlayer antiferromagnetic coupling which has not been reported by any group. By comparing with graphene/CrI3 in which graphene has very weak spin-orbit coupling, the PI showed that the spin-flop transition is a new spin current induced phenomenon. Due to strong sensitivity of CrI3 to moisture, it requires transfer be carried out in the newly constructed glovebox, and the inverted structure with the pre-patterned Pt Hall bar be put underneath the freshly exfoliated and transferred CrI3 flakes. The results were presented at the Gordon Research Conference on Spin Dynamics in Nanostructures at Les Diablerets in July, 2019, and a manuscript on spin current induced spin flop transition is being written.

In addition, the PI has been actively pursuing new quantum effects (e.g., quantum transport due to the phase coherence and spin-orbit scattering, and topological band gap) in van der Waals heterostructures containing 2D layered magnetic materials to introduce and manipulate the induced interactions (e.g., exchange interaction and spin-orbit coupling) in the non-magnetic layered materials such as graphene, transition metal dichalcogenides, and topological insulators. Interesting data have been obtained and will be reported in future papers.

During this report period, the PI has given invited talks which included this NSF funded research at international conferences (Gordon Research Conference in July 2019, Spincaloritronics X in May 2019) and seminars. The graduate students (M. Lohmann, T. Su, and M. Alghamdi) working on this project have given contributed talks at the 2019 American Physical Society March meeting. In addition, the PI has supervised several undergraduate students (Quentin Yurek, Mason Biggerstaff, and Austin Jew) working on the 2D materials and devices.
